person.note: So in the printed editions.

See Introduction 6.2. This woman appears in a fictional context, in a story about the magical properties of חנינא בן דוסא. G. Vermes, Post-Biblical Biblical Studies(Leiden 1975) 189-90, n. 41, suggested that the name may be a midrash (“איכו is an Aramaic optative particle. Hanina is punning”), but he assumed the printed editions had got the name right, which is unlikely, see above, n. 1. This is the correct reading of this name (Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 309-12, n. 60). In the Bible אבי is feminine (2 Kgs 18:2). איבו is the name of a bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 44). The name, as male, is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 83-4; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 153), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. See also J. Levi, Neuhebräisches und chaldäisches Wörterbuch über die Talmudim und Midraschim 1 (Leipzig 1976) 63-4, who suggests the name was the Greek εἴ κε (which he translates as “möchten doch”).

In the tannaitic literature there is no chronological indication for חנינא בן דוסא. However, both PT (e.g. yBer5:6, 9d) and BT (bBer 34b) agree that he was of the generation of Rabban Gamliel at Yabneh, see Introduction 7.5.2.
On the gender of this person see Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 309-12, n. 60.
Described in this tradition as coming from Kafri in Babylonia, see Introduction 6.3.1.
She is described in this tradition as R. Hiyya’s sister, see Introduction 7.5.2.

The Greek̓Αμμία, means “mother” as does the Hebrew/Aramaic אמא. It is recorded among Greek names – WGE, 74. The forms ̓Αμμία and ̓Αμμίας are recorded on Egyptian papyri (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 28).
In Greek – προπεφητευκότας; ἐν Φιλαδελφίᾳ.

Although she is mentioned with other prophets, who were Jews (Judas [probably no. 23], Sheila [no. 5] and Philip [no. 6]’s daughters) there is no indication that she too was Jewish, see Introduction 6.3.2. It should be noted that even her name may not necessarily be interpreted as Semitic, see above, n. 2. The Greek̓Αμμία, means “mother” as does the Hebrew/Aramaic אמא. It is recorded among Greek names – WGE, 74. The forms ̓Αμμία and ̓Αμμίας are recorded on Egyptian papyri (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 28).
Described by Eusebius together with Quadratus, who was active in the time of the Emperor Trajan (97-117 CE – Eus. EH 3:34).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
The inscription is bilingual. Thus in Hebrew. Note that the name here has both the vocalized י and the Palestinian ה suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.3.

The inscription is bilingual. Thus in Greek, see above, n. 2. The Greek̓Αμμία, means “mother” as does the Hebrew/Aramaic אמא. It is recorded among Greek names – WGE, 74. The forms ̓Αμμία and ̓Αμμίας are recorded on Egyptian papyri (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 28).
In Hebrew – הבשנית; in Greek – Σκυθοπολιτίσσα.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 2. The Greek̓Αμμία, means “mother” as does the Hebrew/Aramaic אמא. It is recorded among Greek names – WGE, 74. The forms ̓Αμμία and ̓Αμμίας are recorded on Egyptian papyri (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 28). For the double μ collapsing into a single one, see Introduction 2.3.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3. The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 93a).

note.ref: See above, n. 6. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See above, n. 13. On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3. The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 93a).

person.note: In Hebrew – זי סוכיא.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See above, n. 13. On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3. The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 93a).
See above, n. 6. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See above, n. 13. On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3. The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 93a).

person.note: See Introduction 6.3.4.
On the date of the Samaritan inscriptions, see Introduction 7.6.6.
These are variant readings of the name in the documents. בבתא – PYadin 7, 21, 22, בבתה – PYadin 7, 15, בבתיה – PYadin 27. On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3.
This is the Greek transliteration of this name in the documents (PYadin 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 34c, 35).
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
There is no way of knowing anything about Beruriah’s connections, see D. Goodblatt, “The Bruriah Traditions,” JJS 26 (1975) 68-85. On her chronology see Ilan, Integrating Women, 175-94.
In this tradition she is described as being quoted by R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
On the gender of this person see the ms. tradition for this text and Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 75-6.
Her son is described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This is the Greek transliteration of this Aramaic name in the NT. The explanation of the name in the NT suggests that it derives from the Aramaic word טביא (gazelle). The form is recorded on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 404).
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
The name appears in the text in Syriac characters, see Introduction 2.8.3. The fall of the י causes no problem, since it serves here as vowel, see Introduction 2.7.1.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This text tells of the death of Mary the mother of Jesus, which occurred sometime in the 1st C CE.
A slave of Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.2.
Daughter of R. Hiyya, see Introduction 7.5.2.

The identification of this as the feminine יוחנה is based on the Greek rendition of יוחנן – ̓Ιωάννης. This form (with a single and double ν, see Introduction 2.3.4) is recorded on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 154; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 153).
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.

The name has no standard spelling in Hebrew. It is documented as יחנה, יהחנה, יוחנא, יהוחנא, יוחני. It could be used by both men and women, but was probably more popular with women (see under יוחנא בר מכותא = Yohanan no. 89), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. When there is no clear indication otherwise, the person was identified in this corpus as female. The decision to identify this particular person as female is a random one.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. Simply “Iohana” is also possible. On the collapse of the double consonants see Introduction 2.3.4. This is one of the rare cases of a Latin inscription found in Palestine, see Introduction 2.8.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: This is a fine example of a name being spelt in two different forms on the same ossuary: יוחנא and יהוחנה, indicating how uncertain the spelling was at the time. See above, n. 4. The name has no standard spelling in Hebrew. It is documented as יחנה, יהחנה, יוחנא, יהוחנא, יוחני. It could be used by both men and women, but was probably more popular with women (see under יוחנא בר מכותא = Yohanan no. 89), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. When there is no clear indication otherwise, the person was identified in this corpus as female. The decision to identify this particular person as female is a random one. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. The gender of this person cannot be determined. The decision to identify it as female is a random one.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 4. The name has no standard spelling in Hebrew. It is documented as יחנה, יהחנה, יוחנא, יהוחנא, יוחני. It could be used by both men and women, but was probably more popular with women (see under יוחנא בר מכותא = Yohanan no. 89), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. When there is no clear indication otherwise, the person was identified in this corpus as female. The decision to identify this particular person as female is a random one. In this case the gender of this person was identified by context.
The grandfather of this woman is a well-known high priest mentioned in Josephus (e.g. AJ 18:123). His granddaughter, however, is otherwise unknown.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 4. The name has no standard spelling in Hebrew. It is documented as יחנה, יהחנה, יוחנא, יהוחנא, יוחני. It could be used by both men and women, but was probably more popular with women (see under יוחנא בר מכותא = Yohanan no. 89), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. When there is no clear indication otherwise, the person was identified in this corpus as female. The decision to identify this particular person as female is a random one. The decision to identify this particular person as female is a random one.
In Hebrew – שבאה. On this form see Introduction 3.2.6. Which Sheba exactly is intended is unclear.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 2. The identification of this as the feminine יוחנה is based on the Greek rendition of יוחנן – ̓Ιωάννης. This form (with a single and double ν, see Introduction 2.3.4) is recorded on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 154; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 153). For the single ν, see Introduction 2.3.4. The decision to identify this person as female derives from the ας (rather than male ης) ending, although this could be an idiosyncrasy.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 16. See above, n. 2. For the single ν, see Introduction 2.3.4. The decision to identify this person as female derives from the ας (rather than male ης) ending, although this could be an idiosyncrasy.
See above, n. 5. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 16. See above, n. 2. For the single ν, see Introduction 2.3.4. The decision to identify this person as female derives from the ας (rather than male ης) ending, although this could be an idiosyncrasy. The declension is recorded in the document. The decision to identify this person as female derives from context.

Since this woman is described in the document as emanating from Palestine, and since she bears a name (although not strictly biblical) very common among Jewish women at the time, one may assume, with Tcherikover, CPJ I, 132, that she was Jewish. Zenon, on his visit to Palestine, dealt much with slaves, some of them evidently Jewish, see A. Tcherikover, “Palestine in Light of the Papyri of Zenon,” Tarbiz5 (1934) 42-3 (Hebrew).
The document is internally dated.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. See above, n. 4. The name has no standard spelling in Hebrew. It is documented as יחנה, יהחנה, יוחנא, יהוחנא, יוחני. It could be used by both men and women, but was probably more popular with women (see under יוחנא בר מכותא = Yohanan no. 89), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. When there is no clear indication otherwise, the person was identified in this corpus as female. The decision to identify this particular person as female is a random one. The decision to identify this person as female is a random one.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

See above, n. 4. The name has no standard spelling in Hebrew. It is documented as יחנה, יהחנה, יוחנא, יהוחנא, יוחני. It could be used by both men and women, but was probably more popular with women (see under יוחנא בר מכותא = Yohanan no. 89), and see also Introduction 1.5.2. person.note: The name appears in the text in Syriac characters, see Introduction 2.8.3.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This text tells of the death of Mary the mother of Jesus, which occurred sometime in the 1st C CE.
In Hebrew – שפחה משוחררת.
Many slaves owned by Jews were not themselves Jewish, seeIntroduction 6.3.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of Shemaya and Abtalion of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

See Introduction 6.2. This name is invented only for the purpose of the story in which she appears and explains itself: ההוא דאמר לדביתהו: קונם שאין את נהינת לי עד שתראי לי מום יפה שביך. לר' ישמעאל בר' יוסי. אמר להם: שמא ראשה נאה? אמרו לו: סגלגל. שמא שערה נאה? דומה לאניצי פשתן. שמא עיניה נאות? טרוטות הן. שמא אזניה נאות? כפולות הן. שמא חטמה נאה? בלוס הוא. שמא צוארה נאה? שקוט הוא. שמא כריסה נאה? צבה היא. שמא רגליה נאות? רחבות כשל אוזי. שמא שמה נאה? לכלוכית שמה. אמר להן: יפה קורין אותה לכלוכית, שהיא מלוכלכת במומין. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1.
In this tradition she is described as a contemporary of R. Ishamael, son of R. Yosi, see Introduction 7.5.2.

The editor reconstructs this reading based on two places where the name appears in the document, since it is nowhere documented in full. Yardeni, TAHNDTJD, 121, leaves the [-]ותון uncompleted and claims that DJD 2’s לעות is actually [א]לעזר. In fact she identified another לעזר in this document which the editors could not read.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This is probably a Greek transliteration of this name.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: This is probably another Greek transliteration of this name. The forms Μάρας, Μαρεῖς, Μαρεῦς and Μαρειοῦς are recorded in Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 206; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 187). The declension is recorded in the document.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: On this form see Introduction 2.4.1.1. The name מרי is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 514 [מארי]; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1041-4).
On dating of this cave see Introduction 7.6.5.
On this name being short for Μαρι see Introduction 7.6.5.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 13. On dating of this cave see Introduction 7.6.5.

person.note: This is a straightforward Greek transliteration of this name in the NT. This form, as well as Μάρθας and Μαρθεῖς are recorded on Egytian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 206; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 188).
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
Described in this tradition as the wife of a High priest officiating in the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
On the gender of this person, see Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 307-8; Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 35-6.
Described in this tradition as coming from Kafri in Babylonia, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Her brother is R. Hiyya, see Introduction 7.5.2.
In the initial publication, this name was read [מר]תא, but Misgav, Ossuaries, 46, claims that the ר can be read.
See Introduction 6.3.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 2. This is a straightforward Greek transliteration of this name in the NT. This form, as well as Μάρθας and Μαρθεῖς are recorded on Egytian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 206; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 188). The declension is recorded in the document.
Sukenik, Qobes3 (1934-5) 72-3, suggest that this woman may be identified with Martha no. 2, daughter of Boethus, see Introduction 3.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: I assume this is another transliteration of this name. On the interchange of θ and τ see Introduction 2.1.2.3. It could, likewise, be Μαρα with a mistaken scribal τ added to it, see Introduction 2.7.2, or it could be a letter displacement between τ and α, see Introduction 2.7.3. In Egypt the name Μαρετ[…] is recorded (Preisigke, NB, 206).

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: On dating of Jewish documents from Jerusalem see Introduction 7.6.2.
The name appears in the text in Syriac characters, see Introduction 2.8.3.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This text tells of the death of Mary the mother of Jesus, which occurred sometime in the 1st C CE.

According to the editor, this inscription has found in al-Hijr, deep in the Arabian Peninsula (Hirschberg, EI 12 [1975] 144). Jews of Arabia, on the borders of Palestine, count as Jews of Syria, see Introduction 6.3.1.3.
According to this inscription she is married to a Jew, but the inscription’s provenance (see above, n. 2) and the woman’s name may suggest that she herself was not Jewish.

The inscription is internally dated to the third year of the Nabatean King – Malchus. I assume this is Malchus II (40-75) but it could also be Malchus I, and than the inscription should be dated to 44 BCE.

See Introduction 6.2. צפנת בת פניאל, the daughter of the high priest who was raped in the wake of the destruction of the Temple is found only in BT, and from the context could also refer to the destruction of the first Temple.
Described in association with the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This is Josephus’ rendition of this name. The form Καμῆτις is recorded in Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 163; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 158). Eshel, Zion 64 (1999) 499-500, claims that the name should be read as the Latin Comodus, and that it is documented in Hebrew in 4Q348. Yardeni, who published the document in DJD 27, 301, could not read the name.
See Introduction 6.1.2. On this family name, see Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 608-9.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This is the orthography of the name in the apocryphal book (LXX). The name is recorded on papyri from Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 392; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 297).
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
So in the document, see Introduction 2.8.2. This is the way the name is spelt in the Vulgate for the apocryphal heroin (Dan 13).
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
Associated in the composition with the birth of Jesus.
Whether the name recorded on this ossuary is that of a man or a woman, or whether it is a derivation of שושנה remains uncertain.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Described in this tradition as coming from Kafri in Babylonia, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Described as R. Hiyya’s sister, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This is the only person for whom Josephus uses this name. I assume it is שלמציון because of the use of an almost identical transliteration, notably the use of μψ for מצ (see Introduction 2.1.2.7) in the Akeldama Cave (Ilan, IAAR 1 [1996] 65), see below (Shelamzion no. 18), where שלמצין in Hebrew corresponds to Σελαμψίν.
Probably named after her great great-grandmother (Shelamzion no. 2), see Introduction 3.1.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

These are some of the various names recorded in rabbinic literature (in tannaitic mss.) for the famous queen, wife of king ינאי (Jonathan no. 14 -Ilan, JQR 78 [1987-8] 7, n. 28; Ilan,JSJ 24 [1993] 183-4, n. 7). The form שלמציון is recorded in the two Qumran fragments recently published.
On the Hasmonean Greek names, see Introduction 1.2.4.3.
On the names in the documents from Qumran see Introduction 3.2.8.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: See Introduction 6.3.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

This is an extreme abbreviation of the name, like in tannaitic mss, see above, n. 5. These are some of the various names recorded in rabbinic literature (in tannaitic mss.) for the famous queen, wife of king ינאי (Jonathan no. 14 -Ilan, JQR 78 [1987-8] 7, n. 28; Ilan,JSJ 24 [1993] 183-4, n. 7). The form שלמציון is recorded in the two Qumran fragments recently published. On this form of abbreviation see Introduction 2.4.1.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2.
I assume that this is the same person on both inscriptions, because they seem to come from the same ossuary (Clermont-Ganneau Researches 1, 408).

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 15. In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2. In this case, the abbreviated form is found on the lid of the ossuary. The formal form (שלמציון) is found on its body, see Misgav, Ossuaries, 27.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor. Of course the fragmentary nature of the inscription may render him wrong.

person.note: Since שלמציון is a complicated name, many alternative Greek transliterations are available for it. Yet there is little doubt that this is the name intended. For the missing μ, see Introduction 2.7.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See above, n. 15. In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2.
See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 15. In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2. Another possible reading, suggested by the editor, is שלמשן, though it makes less sense.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 26. Since שלמציון is a complicated name, many alternative Greek transliterations are available for it. Yet there is little doubt that this is the name intended. For the missing μ, see Introduction 2.7.1. In this case the transliteration in Greek is very close to the Hebrew.
This is one variation of the name in this inscription. שלמציון also appears on the same ossuary.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: This seems to be the same name. The endings ה and ון were interchangeable here, see Introduction 2.4.2.3. And see also גוריא-גוריון.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: The inscription is bilingual. The Hebrew has שלמציון. For the Greek, see above, n. 26. Since שלמציון is a complicated name, many alternative Greek transliterations are available for it. Yet there is little doubt that this is the name intended. For the missing μ, see Introduction 2.7.1. The Greek and Hebrew name appears both on the ossuary and on its lid. The Greek appears in different transliterations on the two. On the body we have the official transliteration, see above, n. 2; on the lid, not only is the transliteration not formal, we also observe a displacement of the letters λ and α. For such phenomena, see Introduction 2.7.3. And see also Salome no. 46 of this same cave (perhaps an indication that this is an orthographic idiosyncrasy of the same scribe).
She is also Salome no. 46’s sister. This is proof that the two names are not the same (Ilan, SCI 11 [1991-2] 155-7), see Introduction 3.1.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 15. In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2. For the final ם in a medial position see Introduction 2.7.5. This makes the name appear as two words, which indeed it is, and see also Hananiah no. 72 (=חנןיה).

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See above, n. 15. In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2.

person.note: Misgav, Ossuaries, 122, claims that this is ossuary no. 69.156 of the Israel Antiquities Authority, but CJO published this ossuary completely differently (as no. 287).

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 26. Since שלמציון is a complicated name, many alternative Greek transliterations are available for it. Yet there is little doubt that this is the name intended. For the missing μ, see Introduction 2.7.1. For the interchange of ι and ει see introduction 2.3.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: See above, n. 26. Since שלמציון is a complicated name, many alternative Greek transliterations are available for it. Yet there is little doubt that this is the name intended. For the missing μ, see Introduction 2.7.1. The only other example in our corpus for ζ transliterating צ is in the case of ̓Εζρῶνος for חצרון (Hesron no. 2). For the unusual declension see Introduction 2.3.5.

On dating of the Herodium documents see Introduction 7.6.7. This document seems to b a graffiti of a Roman soldier mentioning the women he adored. The other women – Τρυφήρα and Βο<η>θία (if these are indeed names and not adjectives describing this Shelamzion) – are probably not Jewish, but she is.

See above, n. 2. This is the only person for whom Josephus uses this name. I assume it is שלמציון because of the use of an almost identical transliteration, notably the use of μψ for מצ (see Introduction 2.1.2.7) in the Akeldama Cave (Ilan, IAAR 1 [1996] 65), see below (Shelamzion no. 18), where שלמצין in Hebrew corresponds to Σελαμψίν. The declension is recorded in the document.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

note.ref: See above, n. 15. In many of the inscriptions ציון is abbreviated by the scribe to צין or צון. On such suffixes in general see Introduction 2.4.3.2.
See above, n. 50. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

person.note: See above, n. 26. Since שלמציון is a complicated name, many alternative Greek transliterations are available for it. Yet there is little doubt that this is the name intended. For the missing μ, see Introduction 2.7.1. Note that here μπ (rather than μψ) are used to transliterate מצ.

note.ref: See above, n. 50. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

person.note: On Samaritans in this corpus see Introduction 6.3.4.
On dating of the Samaritan inscriptions, see Introduction 7.6.6.

div.note: This is the correct reading of this name (Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 309-12, n. 60). In the Bible אבי is feminine (2 Kgs 18:2). איבו is the name of a bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 44). The name, as male, is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 83-4; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 153), and see also Introduction 1.5.2.

אמא/אימא means “mother” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 50). On family members as names see Introduction 1.5.1. This name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 68-9). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. The name אמא/אמי is recorded for (male) amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 92-7; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 250-60), and see also Introduction 1.5.2.

בבתא means “pupil of the eye” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 136). בבת is a female name in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 74). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. For Βαβάτας in Maresha, see Oren & Rappaport, IEJ 34 (1984) 144. Whether it is male or female there is unclear.
ברור means “clear, bright, certain, firm” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 191). However, the name may be a distortion of בלוריה, and see under Valeria (L/F).

גוריא means “cub, young lion” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 227). גורא/גורי are (male) names recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 81). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. This is one of the few names in this corpus, which is both male and female, Introduction 1.5.2.
טביא means “gazelle” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 516), see below, n. 2. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.
טוי means “spinning” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 523). The name טיו is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 505).

יוחנה is the feminine form of the biblical יוחנן. It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible, and thus not counted as biblical. For female names derived from male names see Introduction 1.5.3. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.
כלתא means “bride” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 645). On the suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

כרכם means “crocus” or “siege” in Aramaic Jastrow, DTTBYML, 669. כרכומא means “bronze, brazen,” see Jastrow, ibid., 669).Klein, Lĕšonénu 2 (1930) 271-2, thinks she is called thus after her place of origin – Karkemish. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1.
לכלוכית means “moisture, thick nauseating substance” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 711).
לעותא/ליאותא means “labor, earning” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 705). On the ון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1. For an interpretation of the name see DJD2, 116.

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Quite a few inscriptions document this name. The gender of its bearers is not absolutely clear. The form מרי is usually male in amoraic literature (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 536; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1041-4). One inscription, however (Mara no. 4), states categorically that מרה is also called מרתא, a specifically female name. Another inscription (see above, under A/M) makes it clear that this is a male name. Stark, PNPI, 956-7, argues that מרא/ה in Palmyra is feminine. The names were included here under female randomly, except for the clearly male example.
מרתא means “mistress” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). The name is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 695); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 97). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

נשרא means “eagle” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 942). The name in this text is explained as deriving from eagle. The (male) name נשרו is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 761). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

The root עמר means “to stay, dwell” or “wool” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1090-1). For the suffix, see Introduction 2.4.4.1. The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 919); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 106).

The root צפן means “to look up, respect, regard” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1297). For the suffix, see Introduction 2.4.4.1. The name of this woman is clearly derived from a midrash: מעשה באשה אחת וצפנת בת פניאל שמה. צפנת שהכל צופין ביופיה, בת פניאל בתו של כהן גדול ששימש לפני ולפנים (bGit 38a).

קמחא means “flour” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1385). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1. Rabbinic sources and Josephus suggest this was a family name, and see also Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 30-2; Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 285-6.However, in PT this name is related to a woman and a name midrash is appended to it שלחו ואמרו לקמחית: מה מעשים טובים יש בידך? אמרה להן: יבוא עלי אם ראו קורות ביתי שערות ראשי ואמרת חלוקי מימי. אמרין: כל קמחייא קמחין וקימחא דקימחית סולת (yHor 3:5, 47d). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 343.

שושנה in the Bible is the lily (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4). The name is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1118, and שושנת no. 1119). Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Persian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel (C. A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions[The Anchor Bible; New York 1977] 77-116). This women herself is not included in this corpus because, not only is the book a literary creation, it does not even pretend to describe the Greco-Roman period. The name was not popular in Jewish society.

שיליתא means “after-birth” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1563 and 1585). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1. On this name being female, see Rosenthal, “Rabbi Hiyya,” 308-9, n. 58; Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 285-6. The name is recorded for (male) amoraim, (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 644-5; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1548) and for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1124).

The name שלמציון (=“the peace of Zion,” or “the wholeness of Zion”) was not biblical. The form שלמצין is already documented in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 3, 3:28; 4, 8:9, 21:7). On the יון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1. It was a new and popular name for women in the Second Temple period. It went out of use soon after. See Introduction 1.1.2.1.
The root נקי means “clean, clear” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 932). The root ינק means “to suckle” (Jastrow, ibid. 581). For the ין suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1.
